folder: Broome Street & Columbia Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Broome Street, west from and including Columbia Street, showing the printing press factory of R. Hoe and Company on both sides of the street, between Columbia and Sheriff Streets. Both units were demolished, the one on the left is the site of a model apartment, and the other a
playaround; today 1937.
April 4, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, at a later date, showing construction work in progress for the "slum clearance" project. Governor Herbert Lehman was an
active participant.
June 6, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

text:
(1)
Broome Street, west from and including Columbia Street, showing the printing press factory of R. Hoe and Company on both sides of the street, between Columbia and Sheriff Streets. Both units were demolished, the one on the left is the site of a model apartment, and the other a

folder: Columbia Street & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbia Street, west side, south from and including Broome Street,
to and including Grand Street.
April 4, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Columbia Street & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
22 to 4 (left to right) Columbia Street, east side, south from Broome (left), to but not including Grand (right) Streets, showing construction work in progress on the west side of the street (the former site of the main plant of R. Hoe and Co., renowned printing press manufacturers) on a new apartment house. lIncluded is a general view of the surrounding area,
with the Williamsburg Bridge in the background.
June 6, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Columbia Street & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbia Street, east side, from and including Broome Street to Williamsburg Bridge just south of Delancey Street.
October 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Broome Street & Columbia Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Broome Street, east from and including Columbia Street, to the East River. In the background, appears faintly, the Brooklyn shore.
March 26, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Broome Street & Columbia Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Broome Street (left), at the N.W. corner of Columbia (right) Street, showing a Playground occupying the entire block from Columbia to Sheriff Streets, and from Broome to Delancey Streets. Also shown (left) is the 5-story annex building of R. Hoe and Co., renowned printing press Manufacturing firm, now occupied as a broom factory, and a portion of the
Williamsburg Bridge (on Delancey Street).
March 26, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
